Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Violence, stress, and obesity among urban youth in the US

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northwestern University doctoral candidate Lauren Slubowski, supervised by Dr. William Leonard, will explore the biological and cultural impacts of violence upon the health outcomes of urban youth. How does violence impact stress in young people? Specifically, what effect does the stress that can be attributed to violence have on childhood obesity? These questions stem from biological and cultural understandings of the relationship between the environment, stress physiology, and metabolism.

To address these questions, Slubowski will work with a population of low-income, African American adolescents who live in Chicago. She will conduct in-depth interviews and use consensus methods to gain a better understanding of the stressors that youth experience in their neighborhood. Using this information, Slubowski will compare outcomes in a number of psychological stress measures, collect cortisol hormone levels in hair samples, and measure basic health indicators, including eating behavior, activity level, blood pressure, and body mass index (BMI).

This project will illuminate the pathways between violence, everyday experience, stress, and health outcomes among young people in an urban environment. The findings will expand understandings of biocultural pathways to health and disease in a Western population, and involve an age bracket that is understudied in the discipline of anthropology. Further, this project has wider applicability to public health and the topic of health disparities. Funding this project also contributes to the training of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to investigate the comprehensive health impacts of structural inequality, also known as structural violence. Specifically, we wanted to examine the ways in which structural violence affected the daily lives of youth ages twelve to eighteen who were growing up in a low-income neighborhood on Chicago's west side, and how those daily experiences simultaneously affected risk for obesity and for psychosocial stress that can lead to chronic disease later in life. 

The first step was to determine whether there was agreement between youth about the ways that their neighborhood affected their health. Using a cultural consensus design, we conducted sixteen interviews with youth and analyzed those interviews for themes of structural violence. Next, the themes were collected into an inventory of violence exposure. The survey was administered to thirty-five youth, and later a statistical factor analysis test was used to examine inter-respondent agreement. The items most strongly identified by youth were compiled into a survey which was discussed with a focus group of fourteen other youth, who confirmed its appropriateness.

Finally, we collected cross-sectional data from 104 youth. The data included height, weight, blood pressure, and waist circumference, survey data on stress and health behavior, including the survey of structural violence, and hair samples to test for the stress hormone cortisol. Statistical tests were conducted on the cross-sectional data, and interview and focus group transcripts were analyzed to understand how structural violence affects youth and their health.

From the interviews and cultural consensus process, we discovered that youth described three main types of structural violence. The first, structural neglect, included hazards such as abandoned buildings, broken sidewalks, and copious amounts of litter with insufficient sanitation and maintenance. The second kind of structural violence was commercial exploitation, wherein youth noted that there were a plethora of local stores selling unhealthy products and a notable absence of stores selling healthful or positive products. Finally, youth described a lack of access to systems of power, noting that schools, employment, and other resources were inadequate and made it hard to advance themselves.

The structural violence that youth encountered shaped their physical health by increasing risk for disease, injury, and death. Abandoned buildings were expolited by drug dealers, and brought shooting to their streets; corner stores selling only chips, sugary juices, and candy made youth more likely to be overweight; and lack of access to systems of power meant that youth were more likely to get involved with drugs or gangs (and the violence that accompanied them) to gain money and power. 

Structural violence simultaneously affected behavior and emotional/mental health by replicating and reinforcing symbolic violence. Symbolic violence is the consequence of internalizing the message of structural violence: that one's community is of little worth. Youth expressed negative feelings about their neighbors, echoing free-market rhetoric that the failure of their black community was its own doing. Yet youth also acknowledged that the behaviors of youth in the community was a consequence of the conditions surrounding them. Youth noted that apathy was learned because nothing ever improved, and they recognized that the neighborhood was devalued by decision-makers including their local government. They reasoned that gang membership and drug dealing, while unpleasant, were survival tactics for kids whose local neighborhood schools were not academically competitive, and were often spaces of violence.
